abstract_summ: While the fear of delaying surgical care for many of our patients is deeply challenging for us as cancer care providers, we must balance our personal commitment to providing timely and appropriate oncologic care to our cancer patients with our societal responsibility to protect our patients (including those on whom we are operating), co-workers, trainees, families, and community, from undue risks of contracting and propagating COVID-19.Many surgical oncology associations across the globe have come up with triage guidelines for surgical care of cancer patients; however, these are based on expert opinion rather than actual data.Currently routine surgical procedures are at a halt globally, but whether one can delay cancer procedures remains an ethical issue, and still there is no clarity on how women with gynaecological cancers should be managed in these critical times.Due to overall rising cancer incidence and specific concerns, a cohort of cancer patients forms a distinct subset of the population in whom a correct and timely treatment has a huge impact on the outcome.Deferring cancer surgeries for this long period may have a direct impact on the long-term outcomes of cancer patients.
title_summ: ‐ ResponseCOVID‐19 pandemic and health care disparities in head and neck cancer: Scanning the horizonThe COVID-19 Pandemic and Implications for Gynaecologic Cancer CareTo Do or Not to Do?—Ocular oncology practice guidelines during COVID-19 pandemic-An expert consensus.A Review of Cancer Surgery Triage Guidelines in COVID-19 PandemicSurgical decision-making and prioritization for cancer patients at the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic:A multidisciplinary approachDo we really need guidelines for HRA during COVID‐19 pandemic?
title_abstract_phrases: While the fear of delaying surgical care for many of our patients is deeply challenging for us as cancer care providers, we must balance our personal commitment to providing timely and appropriate oncologic care to our cancer patients with our societal responsibility to protect our patients (including those on whom we are operating), co-workers, trainees, families, and community, from undue risks of contracting and propagating COVID-19.Many surgical oncology associations across the globe have come up with triage guidelines for surgical care of cancer patients; however, these are based on expert opinion rather than actual data.Currently routine surgical procedures are at a halt globally, but whether one can delay cancer procedures remains an ethical issue, and still there is no clarity on how women with gynaecological cancers should be managed in these critical times.Surgical decision-making and prioritization for cancer patients at the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic: A multidisciplinary approachIn the midst of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, governmental agencies, state medical boards, and healthcare organizations have called for restricting “elective” operations to mitigate the risk of transmission of the virus amongst patients and healthcare providers and to preserve essential resources for potential regional surges of COVID patients.COVID‐19 pandemic and health care disparities in head and neck cancer: Scanning the horizonThe COVID‐19 pandemic has profoundly disrupted head and neck cancer (HNC) care delivery in ways that will likely persist long term.
